social_posts.post_text:
🎄 Top 3 Foods at the Downtown Holiday Market in Penn Quarter in Washington D.C. 🎄 

1) Hot cinnamon-dusted, cream-filled Churros from Alexa’s Empanadas (10/10) @alexas_empanadas 

2) Bavarian Pretzel from Taste of Germany 🥨 (7/10) - highly recommend the hot mustard — they also have traditional German treats like Lebkuchen, Stollen Cakes, and Marzipan!

3) Migue’s Mini Donuts (10/10) - and you get to pick your own toppings!! They are DELICIOUS and made fresh right in front of you. 🍩 @migues_minis_dc_ 

And while you’re at the market, don’t forget to check out the 70+ local artesians selling their crafts and goods! There is also live music to get you in the spirit as you shop!

#washingtondc #dcmarket #christmasmarket #downtownholidaymarket @downtownholidaymarket #visitwashingtondc #washingtondcfood #foodietribe #dcfoodie #washingtondcartist #pennquarter #downtowndc #dceats #dcfood #dclife

🇧🇧 Happy December from Barbados! 🇧🇧 

My intention was to share this on December 1, but per usual these days, I forgot. 🤷🏼‍♀️ 🤰🏼 

I am excited to experience Christmas in Barbados! The kids are putting on a Christmas performance at school, the island is packed with pop up vendor markets and I’ve been seeing Christmas decor all over the island! 

Today I have a day full of Holiday baking planned. It’s funny what you can and can’t find on the island. I needed Graham crackers and apparently — that’s not a thing here. Ha! I can’t find them anywhere!  Oh and the basic Christmas candy I am used to in the USA is also hard to nail down — I brought back some from the my trip, but not enough for my pregnant cookie cravings! Definitely still adjusting to island life! 🇧🇧 

👉🏼👉🏼 Do you have plans for the Holiday? Are you traveling or staying home this year? 

📸: Photo courtesy of my tripod & 10 second timer

#barbados #bigbravenomad #barbadostoday #barbadoslife #bajan #bajanbaby #americanexpat #visitbarbados #barbadosbeach #beachchristmas #carribeanlife #easterncaribbean #barbadostravel

image_entities.entity: finding out i have placenta previa and a
c-section is the only option for a safe delivery.

social_posts.post_text:
I love giving birth. For me, it’s the best part of the entire process. It’s powerful, it’s intense, it’s the most rewarding thing I’ve done in my life. Ask anyone who knows me IRL - I *love* talking about birth.

✅ I’ve had an induction (vaginal birth with an epidural)
✅ I’ve had a non-medicated, fully natural birth.

I intended to have a third fully natural birth. Finding out I have complete placenta previa with my 3rd (and last) baby has been nothing short of heartbreaking. I got my hopes up before every ultrasound — and was crushed each time we realized the placenta didn’t move.  I am grieving the experience I won’t have of skin to skin, of nursing right away, of being mentally and physically present for all the first moments I’ve waited for for 9 months. I’m grieving because I know how powerful and strong and capable my body is and how good it is at giving birth. I’m grieving the simple recovery of Vaginal birth. I’m also grieving because this isn’t what I wanted — and it’s selfish, but true. I have cried a river of tears.

C-Sections scare me. I’ve never had surgery in my life. An now, not only will I have surgery, but it’s in a new country with different healthcare standards. It’s overwhelming to me and I feel very scared. I’ve always wondered how the heck mothers recover from massive abdominal surgery AND care for a newborn/other kids. These mothers are the real unsung heroes of the birthing world.

👉🏼👉🏼 So, if you’re a c-section mama, I’d love to hear all your tips and advice for recovery and for mentally preparing for the surgery. Also any tips for how Jimmy can help me through the days and weeks after.

And if you feel like commenting something negative or unhelpful, don’t waste your time - I’ll just delete it. I don’t have the mental space for ignorance right now. ✌🏼

#birthwithoutfear #csection #csectionrecovery #csectionmama #birthstory #givebirth #thirdkid #placentaprevia

🇧🇧 We did it! We had a baby in Barbados! 🇧🇧 

👉🏼 Watch to the end for the gender & name

2 weeks ago we had our third and final baby here in Barbados. 🇧🇧 Our sweet little Bajan Baby. It was a scheduled c-section at 37 weeks due to complete placenta previa. 

Our baby was born chubby, beautiful, and most importantly - healthy. 🙌🏼

Thank you to all of you who have DM’d me the past 2 weeks asking how I’m doing and about baby. I am so grateful to know so many of you kept us in your thoughts and prayers. And thank you for giving us the grace and space we needed to have our baby to ourselves in these first precious days.

🎶: Rubble to Rubble by @wilderado_ 

#bajan #barbados #barbadoslife #barbados🇧🇧

⛵️I’ve never sailed a day in my life, BUT my kids are! And I am so excited to be a part of it! ⛵️

A huge perk of living on an island in the Caribbean is the unique experiences my kids are getting. They would have never learned to sail where we lived in the US.

Watching a bunch of 5-9 year olds sailing boats by themselves was surprising and awesome!  It was incredible watching my own two go from being scared (literally crying) to sailing with a @setsailbarbados instructor in less than 2 hours. Their instructors are made of pure patience and we can’t wait for the next lesson! ⛵️

👉🏼👉🏼Have you ever sailed a boat? Should I also take lessons? 

#barbados #barbadoslife #caribbeanlife #islandlife #barbados🇧🇧 #barbadosbeach #sailinstagram #expats #barbados246🇧🇧 #sailingclub @barbados_cruising_club #setsail #setsailbarbados #bajan #sportingbarbados #livingoverseas #caribbeankids #lovebarbados

❤️ My life long Galentine ❤️

I wanted to shared some LOVE with all of you today with a little guide to The Big Island in Hawaii!

Here are 7 things we LOVED:

🏝️ Green Sand Beach: I have a whole Insta  post on this beach and getting there. 100% worth the effort.

🧺 Local Markets: We had the chance to visit 3 different outdoor markets across the island and loved each one. You can support local businesses and find some fantastic food at excellent prices! Waimea Farmers Market has an EPIC playground co-located! 

🌋 Visit Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, obviously. I have an entire blog on this park outlining exactly where to hike and what to see! (link in bio)

🌊 Night Swim with Manta Rays: This was a life bucket list item for me! I absolutely recommend Dan’s boat. He’s got the absolute best (and safest) equipment — @mantaadventures 

🤿 Snorkel: Our favorite spots to get in and see the sea life up close were: Honaunau Bay (open sea cove off big rocks) and Kahalu’u Beach Park (huge & safe snorkel area with restrooms, parking, and showers)

🍧 Eat Shaved Ice: You can’t visit Hawaii and not eat shaved ice — our fave spot was in our hotel at Ululani’s Hawaiian Shaved Ice — a MUST visit on the big island. @ululanishawaiianshaveice 

🐢 Learn about the Big Islands rich history and one of the 5 National Historic Sites — my favorite was Kaloko-Honokōhau National Historic Site where we learned about ancient  fishponds and saw a huge population of sea turtles. (Don’t forget to get Junior Ranger badges!)

👉🏼👉🏼Have you visited the Big Island? What did you LOVE most?

➡️ Don’t forget to check out my complete guide; What to do in Hawaii Volcanoes National Park with Kids (link in bio)

💫T W E L V E 💫 

Twelve years ago we were 22 and 24 saying “I Do” as two 2LTs on Pensacola NAS. In typical military fashion, I was deploying a few weeks later. We thought we were going to have a “big wedding” later.  We planned to go to the courthouse in jeans by ourselves, but our immediate family refused to not come. 

I bought a dress online and didn’t wear my “real” dress.  We thought we’d have a big wedding later.

We got the base chaplain to marry us on an outdoor pavilion on base in our thrown together ceremony. I made my own fake bouquet, bought the bridesmaids matching sandals at Target. Afterall, we were having a “big wedding” later.

But later came and went. We deployed again. And again. We had a baby and then another right after that. We moved and moved again and moved again. We started traveling. 

And later came and went again. We celebrated 5 years, then 10. We had another baby.

And here we are. 12 years into forever. It’s gone by so fast and so slow. I don’t even remember my life before you. It’s been the best, hardest, and craziest 12 years. 

We may not have had that “big wedding” — but we did build a big life together.

I love you today more than I ever could have at 24. I can’t wait to see what lucky 13 brings.

I love you to the moon and back and back and back….

#bigbravenomad #anniversaries #twelveyearslater #twelveyearstogether #happyanniversarymylove #militarylove #militaryfamily #militaryspouse

REMINDER: To be an outdoorsy person, you don’t have to be hiking huge mountains or doing something extreme every day! 

Just got outside and find something nearby! 

This State park was about 30 minutes from our house in California and a VERY short 0.2 mile trail to get to this viewpoint. Nothing strenuous or crazy!

📸: Julia Pfeiffer Burns State Park, Big Sur

🇨🇷 5 Must Do Adventures in La Fortuna, Costa Rica 🇨🇷 

- 🌳Ziplining: We went Ziplining at Arenal Paraíso Resort! The guides were amazing and you’ll see 2 waterfalls, a river, and gorgeous canopy on cables that are as long as 845 meters! (Kids were 4 & 6)  You also get FREE access to Paraiso Hot Springs after the canopy tour!

- 🌁 Mistico Hanging Bridges: Walk in the canopy of the cloud forest! Definitely eat lunch in their cafe - the best volcano views of any place around Arenal. 

- 🌋 Guided Volcano Hike: We hiked in Parque Nacional Volcán Arenal with a guide named Cristian. He was absolutely amazing & we learned so much from him. (Booked thru Jimmy at Pura Vida Tours!)

- ☕️ North Fields Coffee, Chocolate & Sugar Cane Tour: This was so fun and interactive. Not to mention amazing coffee and THE BEST chocolate! We learned so much and had the best time on this! Don’t miss this when visiting La Fortuna!

- 🦥 Find wild sloths: I booked thru Airbnb - Sloth Tour hosted by Rebecca - and this was our absolute favorite thing we did in La Fortuna. We trekked around with an ecologist finding WILD sloths. After the trek they had coffee and delicious fruit for us. 10/10 recommend. 

👉🏼👉🏼 Have you been to Costa Rica? What’s your favorite activity?

🏔️ Three Can’t Miss Spring Hikes in Mt Rainier National Park 🏔️ 

We visited in early June and the snow was still thick on the mountains and the Sunrise area of the park was still closed. BUT we found three amazing trails that showcase the beauty of this Washington park.

🥾: Silver Falls - is only 0.5 miles from the Grove of Patriarchs trailhead parking lot. The hike is gorgeous with fairy bridges and incredible fauna. Get there early as this is a tiny parking area and a very popular hiking spot. If you park at the Silver Falls trail head, it’s ~3 miles RT to see the falls! 

🥾: Grove Of the Patriarchs - this easy 1.5-mile loop trail walks along the Ohanapecosh River edge, over a suspension bridge, and around a boardwalk to see Some of the biggest, oldest trees in the Washington Cascades!

🥾: Skyline Loop Trail - I suggest doing this strenuous 5.5 mile trail clockwise. The trail climbs to Panorama Point, then connects back to Skyline Trail where you’ll hike past Myrtle Falls and finally back to Paradise.  If there is snow, I suggest renting snow shoes or spikes depending on the conditions. We did this hike in June and it was still heavily covered in snow. This is THE BEST trail for panoramic view of Mount Rainier and al his glaciers.

⛷️: Bonus -

#bigbravenomad #mtrainier #washintonstate #hikewashington #nationalparks #visittheusa #skylinetrail #mountrainier #rainier #kidswhohike #familyadventures #adventurefamily #nationalparkgeek #findyourpark

🌿 5 Can’t Miss Spots in Olympic National Park 🌿 

🌲 1 - Hoh Rainforest: Hall of Mosses -  This trail is by far the most popular and most stunning trail in this area.  The Hall of Mosses is a very easy 0.8-mile trail that takes you through a living fairytale of moss and giant trees.  While hiking, keep your eyes out for the famous Banana Slug! 

🪨 2 - Ruby Beach - There is a very shore 0.25-mile trail from the parking area down to the beach.  This gorgeous beach has a large pool created by the Cedar Creek where the kids can play safely.  If you do this trail during low tide, it’s possible that you’ll be able to explore the tidepools to find starfish and other creatures. 

🌲 3 - Marymere Falls:  To get here it is an easy 1.7-mile RT trail. This entire trail is gorgeous and the falls view is the turn around point.

🪨 4- Rialto Beach: No hiking is required to enjoy the beauty of Rialto Beach as its steps from the parking area. However, I recommend trying the  Hole In The wall Trail! We did it with the kids pretty easily! At Rialto Beach keep your eyes out for some amazing wildlife like sea lions, whales, and even Eagles perched in the trees. 

🌲 5 - Sol Duc Falls: To get here, it is an easy 1.6-mile RT trail with only 200 feet of elevation gain.  This trail is extremely rewarding. The bridge that crosses over the rushing water is absolutely stunning.  Cross the bridge and look back! 

👉🏼 What’s your favorite spot in Olympic National Park?

———————————————————
Check out my Olympic highlight or head to the blog to see The Best Family Hikes in Olympic and my full 3-Day Olympic Itinerary to learn more! Follow us @BigBraveNomad for all your National Park guides and itineraries!

🌲Redwood National Park 🌲

📌 Save this post 📌 

Something I miss the most from the USA are these trees. The giant redwoods in California are some of the most awe inspiring parts of nature. While there are many places to see Redwoods in CA, you won’t see any as big as the ones in Redwood National Park. 

👉🏼 Have you ever been to a Redwood grove?

——————————-
Redwood National Park is actually called Redwood National and State Parks because it’s the National Park lands plus 3 California State Parks that make up the entire park. From north to south, you can expect to drive for about 2 hours.

🗺 This hike is in Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park. The trail is Cathedral Trees Trail.

🥾 Cathedral Trees Trail is an easy 3 miles. 

🚨 HOWEVER, due to the complex nature of this national park, I recommend hiring a local guide for at least one day of your adventure. We partnered with @redwood_adventures to take us off the beaten path, explain the ecology, show us the true history of the area and take us to the lesser known, but arguably the largest Redwoods in the region. Locals are gold mines of knowledge & our guide (Justin) with Redwood Adventures is a local and an ecologist. (Support Local Businesses!)

👩🏼‍💻 I’ve got a full blog on Everything you need to know about Redwood National Park in my bio & an entire IG Highlight with everything we did during our visit.

———————————————————
Visiting U.S. National Parks this year? Follow us @bigbravenomad for National Park Guides for families and tips about visiting the parks

Pinnacles National Park is one of the underrated Parks in California. Often overlooked for bigger parks like Sequoia and Yosemite — this National Park is worth the visit. The park is divided into two sides (East & West) and are not connected by roads. So you will either have to hike over Mountain to see both sides, drive around, or pick a side! 

My two favorite hikes in Pinnacles National park:

🪨 EAST PINNACLES:
Bear Gulch Cave Trail: This moderate1.5-mile loop trail is moderate.  Bear Gulch Cave Trail starts at the Moses Spring Parking Area.  Take the 0.2 mile Moses Spring trail to where it T’s and go left toward the cave.  You’ll then be climbing through the amazing talus cave.  Once through the cave, you will emerge at the Bear Gulch Reservoir.  From here, you head up toward the Rim Trail which takes a scenic but less daring course along the rim of the gorge. The trails reunite back at the Moses Spring Trail. 

**The Bear Gulch Cave is open seasonally - bring a flashlight for the cave.

🪨 WEST PINNACLES:
Juniper Canyon Trail: This 2.5 mile trail is moderate.  Just before the start of the switch backs that lead up to the Tunnel Trail, there is an absolutely epic view of the Pinnacles.  If you’re feeling frisky and have extra energy, I highly suggest adding the High Peaks trail down to Tunnel Trail to make a loop.  This makes the hike about 4.5 miles.

👉🏼 Have you ever been to Pinnacles?

Comment and tell me: Have you ever been to an all inclusive resort? 

This was our first experience and while this is not our typical travel style — we all LOVED it. It was very pricey, but the 24/7 comforts made up for the price. Full disclosure, we paid $2,982.12 for 4 nights. 🫣 But there are many all inclusive that are not this expensive and many that run deals during low seasons! Sign up for email alerts from resorts you’ve got your eye on. We were attending a wedding, so we stayed where the wedding was.

Here’s what we loved most:

- Kids club from 9-5 (Ages 4-12) My kids never wanted to leave. When we picked them up for meals, they didn’t want to go with us.
- Daily resort activities: everything from Fire Shows, painting classes, foam parties, cooking classes, Spanish classes, pool side massages, live music, and more
- 24/7 Room Service (SO AMAZING)
- In-Room Babysitting Services 
- Baby amenities like sterilizers, cribs, and strollers
- Swim Up Bar
- 5 on-site restaurants
- Family Lounge
- Beach side Cabanas
- Inner Resort Shuttle Service (golf carts)
- Full Spa (and even a kids spa!!)
- Personal Concierge for every room 
- Fully stocked room fridges
- And soooo much more! 

We’ll definitely be adding all-inclusive resorts into our rotation of trips in the future. It was incredibly relaxing to have every single thing taken care of for our whole stay! I can’t wait for the next all inclusive family trip!

#allinclusive #bigbravenomad #mexicotravel #visitméxico #familytravels #mexicanvacation #familyof5 #bigfamilytravel #travel #allinclusiveresort #allinclusivevacation #modernromancetravel @modern_romance_travel #travelwithkids #travelfam #travelwithbaby #babycantravel

✈️ And we’re off! ✈️ 

For those of you who are new here, Hi! I’m Tavia - the face behind Big Brave Nomad! I love breakfast burritos, National Parks, and doing puzzles. We moved to Barbados a year ago and have 2 more years left on the island. i’ve got 2 big kids and a baby nomad. We’ve visited 26 countries, 48 US States, & 50 U.S. National Parks with our kids.

This summer we are off on a 9-10 week trip through central and South America. We decided that spending my husband’s parental leave traveling together would be more of a bonding experience than staying at home getting lost in the day to day. 
 
This trip we made it a point to pack light and “backpack” our way through 6 countries. So, what you see in the first photo is everything we brought with us. 4 backpacks and 1 checked bag (which has the baby’s travel cot inside).

If you have any questions about packing light, Central or South America with kids and a baby, about US National Parks, or about life as US Nationals living abroad — let me know! 

———————————————————

🍧 Granizadas are the Guatemalan version of shaved ice….but add a little ✨ spice ✨ 

🍧 They start with shaved or crushed ice and add any combination of the following: syrups, fruits, condensed milk, cooked fruits and their syrups, tamarind, camote (sweet potatoes), nance (sweet yellow cherry), just to name a few of the possible ingredients for the sweet granizadas; you add pepitoria molida (ground pumpkin seeds), Takis, chips, salt and lime-lemon juice for the salty granizadas.

🍧 I am obsessed with the Fresa y Piña con Leche. (Strawberry and Pineapple with sweet milk). The kids like anything with sprinkles or rainbows or intense sweet.

🍧 The Granizada stands were all over the streets around Lake Atitlan, so we tried a few different vendors as the days passed. A day at the lake isn’t complete without one!l

Fun Fact: Granizadas is the Spanish term for hailstorm

👉🏼 Which type of Granizada would you prefer: Sweet or Savory? 

#bigbravenomad #granizada #guate #guatemala #visitguatemala #lakeatitlan #panajachel #guatemalan #granizadas #guatemalanfood #guatemalatravel #travelguatemala #guategram

🔸 TIKAL NATIONAL PARK 🔸

If you’re adding Guatemala to your must see list, then Tikal must also be on this list. Tikal is the largest and possibly oldest of the Maya cities. (Also if you’re visiting Belize, Tikal is a short drive from the Western border of Belize)

7 Tips for Visiting Tikal

🔸 Hire a guide. We hired Jose from Tikal Tours/Expeditions. He’s incredibly knowledgeable about everything Guatemala. He was also fantastic with the kids.

🔸 Wear sunscreen - there is shade in the park but many of the temples are out in the open. Sunscreen and a sun hat will go a long way.

🔸 Wear bug spray. It’s the literal jungle. There are many bugs.

🔸 Bring water & cash. There is a small refreshment stand in the middle of the park to get a cold drink, but it’s cash only.

🔸 There are restrooms located in the center of the park. So, don’t feel like you need to hold it! 

🔸 Take the free shuttle from the entrance to the center of the park to save yourself a 30-40 min walk into the temples. (TIKAL is huge) Be sure to tip the driver.

🔸 Keep an eye out for Toucans, Monkeys, Pizote, Crocodiles, Turkeys, and if you’re very lucky - Jaguar! 

Park Entrance Fee: ~$20 USD or 150 Q per adult for each day. Children under 12 are free. 

Have you ever been to any of the Mayan Temples or Ruins?

A must do in Antigua, Guatemala is take a Jade Class!

J & L took a 2 hour class through @casadeljade 

We showed up a little early, so we got a a full guided tour though their Jade museum and learned about different types of Jade found in Guatemala. We also learned some history on how Jade was (and still is) used by Mayans.

Once the class started it was amazing to see a raw piece of jade turn into a shiny creation. The teacher was extremely helpful and knowledgeable (20 years of experience!). Mid way through the class they brought us all coffee, water, and juice! (Even C and I had some even tho we were just watching!)

Cost: $118 for 2 people ($59 pp)
Length: 2 Hours
Experience: Totally worth it! 

L made a Mayan Temple (Atitlan)
J surprised C with by making her a bracelet. 

Fun Fact: Jade represents eternity. Mayas buried their kings adorned with jade masks and pectorals, considering jade the ultimate passport to the afterlife. For the Maya, green was the most precious color. Green represented the life-giving water of the Sacred Cenotes.

———————————————————

🌋 🍕 Would you eat a pizza made in a real volcano? 🍕 🌋 

📌 Save this reel if Guatemala is on your list 📌 

🌋 This is Volcan Pacaya about an hour outside of Antigua, Guatemala.

🥾 If you want this pizza, you’re going to have to work for it. The hike up Volcan Pacaya is 3.5 miles RT, but the elevation change is around 1500 feet over the 1.75 miles up. 

💰 We paid 400Q or $51 USD for a large pizza and it was totally worth it. These guys hike in all the ingredients and supplies every day. 

🍕 Was it good? Surprisingly, it was delicious! I had my doubts - but now I’m a believer!!

**This hike is also in a National Park, so expect to pay 100Q to enter the park to do the hike.

🇪🇨 Have you considered a visit to the Ecuadorian Amazon? 🇪🇨 

📌 Save this post 📌 

We had the chance to spent 3 nights in the Ecuadorian Amazon with @lacasadelsuizo - It was a core memory experience for all of us. |Hosted|

👉🏼 SWIPE to see some of our activities! 

Here’s what you can expect when coming to Casa Del Suizo:
🛶 A jungle lodge accessible only by boat 
🛶 Rooms to accommodate varying family or group sizes. 
🛶 3 meals a day included in your stay (delicious food too!)
🛶 A full bar for evening libations 
🛶 A gorgeous swimming pool right next to the dining area and bar with epic views of the Rio Napo
🛶 A game room with a big screen for movie nights 
🛶 THE BEST PART: 2 daily activities of your choice. We did many including a ceramics class, Caiman spotting, chocolate making, an indigenous medicine class with a Shaman, a jungle trek, Balsa ride, and more! They also have a canopy tour, animal sanctuary, and river tubing. 

If you’re looking to explore more of authentic Ecuador and not just the Galapagos, I highly recommend adding La Casa Del Suizo to your itinerary! Everyone in your family will thank you! 

 I am happy to answer any questions you have about staying here!

🇪🇨 Hot Springs with Kids? Yes. 🇪🇨 

📌 Save this post 📌 

Termas Papallacta is located about 90 minutes East of Quito & only 45 minutes from the airport. This gem of Ecuador is a a steamy getaway high in the Andes Mountains. We were lucky enough to stay 3 days and 2 nights soaking in the natural mineral water. We were so relaxed our entire stay. |Hosted|

☁️ A couple steps outside our Bungalow door were hot springs where we could enjoy the hot mineral water. These are not open to the public, so we often had them all to ourselves.
☁️ The on-site restaurants have really good food and coffee. (I recommend the Empanadas) 
☁️ @termas.papallacta Spa not only offers incredible treatments for adults, but kids can get massages too! Both of our big kids had massages!
☁️ Children are welcome everywhere. I loved that they were included because kids need to relax too! 
☁️ You can choose from three areas to soak: The pools at the cabins (if you’re an overnight guest), the Spa pools with 5 different hydro massage pools, or the Balneario which has 10 different pools.
☁️ @termaspapallacta has an entrance to Cayambe-Coca National Park where guests can take a variety of mountain hikes! 
☁️ The staff is incredible & attentive to your every need.
☁️ Termas Papallacta sits at an elevation of about 3,250 meters in the Andes Mountains, but there is an on site medical team if you feel any affects from the altitude 

While Termas Papallacta is an easy day trip from Quito, I highly recommend staying the night to have time to enjoy the full spa, the family cabins, & all the pools!

 I am happy to answer any questions you have about staying here!

📸 Should you hire a photographer on your trip? 

Yes. YES. Resounding YES.

We have hired a photographer a few times on our trips and I always am so happy I did. Here are some tips for hiring a photographer on your trip:

📌 Save this post 📌 

1) Search around. My go-to places to find someone are @flytographer , Airbnb Experiences, and I will even do a little googling just to be sure I get the colors and interactive photos I like. 

2) Reach out before the shoot to let your photographer know what your thinking or to ask them what they suggest is the best spot, best time, and let them know your family size/dynamic 

3) Do not stress about outfits. In Hawaii I was SO stressed about colors and hair and everything being perfect. In Colombia, we quite literally put on outfits we had with us and we’re out the door in under 30 minutes. I love both sets of photos just the same.

4) Before you book a photographer, be sure you know what you’re getting. Some photographers charge a fee for the shoot and then charge for you to receive the photos. Others charge one fee and you get all the edited images for download. I prefer the latter.

5) Ask for interactive shots as well as staged smiling photos. I love all of our Cartagena photos, but the lifestyle ones are my fave.  @cruellsphoto was absolutely fantastic in Colombia and I highly highly recommend booking her. 

Let me know if you have any questions about hiring a photographer on your next trip! 

📍 Cartagena, Colombia

🇬🇹 Mayan Weaving Class 🇬🇹 

📌 Save this post

👉🏼 Do you ever take classes to immerse deeper into the culture and history of the place your visiting? 

Charletta and I took a Mayan weaving classes with @tintemaya in San Juan La Laguna - a little town that sits on the shores of Lake Atitlan. It was an incredible experience and we both have a hand made souvenir along with a connection to and deeper appreciation of the Mayan women. We both chose to make a “bufanda” or scarf! 

Things to know before you book a Mayan weaving class:
🧵- Tinte Maya is a cooperative of Mayan women who teach the craft of dying the thread with natural dye and using a back strap  loom to create a scarf or table piece
🧵 The dying class is 3 hours and the weaving class is 3 hours, but you can do one without the other or both together.
🧵 Mayan is their first language, Spanish second, and English is their third — expect some hand gesturing and repetitive single words. 
🧵 While Mayan women make back strap weaving look easy and fast - it is not at all. It’s tedious to learn and takes patience. Come with an open mind and a strong back! It’s worth it! 
🧵 We paid 300Q for only the weaving class (pp) - but expect this to fluctuate with the economy 
🧵- 7 is the the youngest age I would recommend for this class & only if the child can sit and work for a long period.

When you take this class, you’ll come away from this experience with a new respect for the colorful swaths of woven fabrics lining the street markets. You’ll also have a deeper respect for the traditions of Mayan women and their contributions to their family and communities. 

I am happy to answer any questions you have about taking a weaving class in Guatemala!

When you’re in the National Parks, sunrise is always the best time to experience the most magical parts of the park without anyone else around. Always explore outside of bankers hours!

This day we woke up at 3am to drive into Yosemite and out to hike Sentinel Dome. We had the entire dome to ourselves for over an hour as we watched the sun rise over half dome. It was absolutely incredible. 

Hiking with kids at sunrise doesn’t have to be hard. Here are 3 things we do to make it worth it:

🥾: Being a reward for the end of the hike, something they can work toward (usually a snack of some kind) 
🥾: Make sure not to plan anything strenuous after about 11 or 12
🥾: Prep absolutely everything the night before so when we wake, we just get dressed and hop in the car.

—> Have you done a sunrise hike with kids?

🏔️ 🍂 Fall in the Rockies 🍂 🏔️ 

It was September when we stood on the shores of Dream Lake and hiked through a fall orange forest. I’m missing cool crisp mountain air more than I can say. I’m missing the open road. The National Parks. The endless outdoor adventures with my kids. I can’t wait to get back here.

📌 SAVE THIS REEL 📌 

🗺: This hike is in the Bear Lake section of Rocky Mountain National Park. The trailhead is co-located with the Bear Lake Trailhead — you’ll veer left almost as soon as you start the trail.  Their are restrooms and a cash only souvenir kiosk at the trailhead too.

🥾: This is an easy 2.2 mile trail. 

🏔: Dream Lake is backdropped by the 12,713-foot Hallett Peak and 12,324-foot Flattop Mountain. In between the two mountains is the Tyndall Gorge, with the Tyndall Glacier *barely* visible from this angle.

🎫: RMNP now has ticketed entry from May - late Oct. So be sure your ticket includes Bear Lake if you want to do this hike. Also - it is a very very popular hike, so you likely won’t be alone here.

💻: Be sure to check out my full guide to Rocky Mountain National Park on the blog and my Instagram Highlight to see videos and photos with tips about our time in the park.

🌺 Night Swim with Manta Rays 🌺 

📌 Save this Reel 📌 

We took our kids to swim in the Pacific Ocean at night to see Manta Rays in the wild on our trip to the Big Island. This was our birthday gift to our daughter for her 7th birthday. Even tho they are excellent swimmers and love to ocean swim, I wasn’t sure how they would do. Would they be scared? Would they cry? Would they even get in the water? 

My son (5) didn’t want to get in the water at first, but at the last minute he joined us. The four of us were in absolute awe as the manta rays did loops with mouths wide open as they came up for plankton. My kids squealed and chirped with pure joy as we watched the gentle giants have a feast. It was a night I will never ever forget.

Adventure doesn’t end when you have kids, it truly begins. 

COMPANY: We went with @mantaadventures and am so glad we did. They were extremely professional, took safety seriously, and have the best board set up of any company.

LOCATION: Big Island, Hawaii

👉🏼 Did you know Barbados is the only Caribbean Island that is not a volcanic island? It was formed by sediment being scaled off the South American plate as it went below the Caribbean plate! 

🇧🇧 Bathsheba, Barbados is home to a rocky Atlantic sea coast. At low tide you’ll find these amazing sea pools where you can swim and relax. Or you can go under the coral rock formations and swim in shaded pools. 

Bathsheba is one of Barbados’ most underrated spots in my opinion.

🇧🇧 Tips for visiting Bathsheba:
- Be there at low tide
- Wear water shoes
- Bring goggles to see the fish and creatures living in the pools 
- Walk the beach after to find some incredible sea shells
- Don’t forget sunscreen & bug spray!
- Bring cash to get a lollee from the ice cream truck or lunch in one of the local spots

🇬🇹 Indian Nose Hike (Rostro Maya Hike) 🇬🇹 

📌 Save this Post 📌 

Today is National Hiking Day! So, let’s talk about a really cool hike we did on our trip to Guatemala! We did this with a guide, a 6 year old, 8 year old, and a 6 month old.

🥾 Hire a guide. The hike is doable without one, but you have to pay landowners at 2 different spots. It’s easier to find the trailhead & navigate payments with a local. We hired Matt from Geo Travel Guatemala & he was so amazing.

🏃🏽 The trail is approximately 2 miles RT with an elevation change of 951 feet. Be prepared to climb! 

☀️ This hike is most well known for being at Sunrise, but we chose to start around 10 AM. It was perfect and we didn’t have any crowds. It also meant we weren’t waking at 3AM to meet the guide.

🥾 Wear comfortable, sturdy shoes. The trail is very muddy in some areas and the trail is short but very steep in areas! 

☀️ Don’t forget sunscreen, a hat, and bug spray. The trail is mostly shaded, but the overlooks are quite sunny. Dengue is endemic to Guate, so be vigilant!

🇬🇩 Grenada: 10 Things You Can’t Miss 🇬🇩 

📌 Save this Reel 📌 

For Thanksgiving weekend we hopped on a short 25-45 minute flight from Barbados to Grenada. We were blown away by the Spice Isle! 

Here are 10 things you can’t miss when visiting Grenada:
1. Spice Markets - This is the Spice Island! Be sure to pick up Grenadian nutmeg, cinnamon, clove, turmeric, & more! 
2. Snorkeling - Spot live conch, tropical fish, sea horses, and even an underwater sculpture garden!
3. Welcome Rock - Arguably the best views on the island are from Welcome Rock!
4. The River Antoine Distillery - this is the oldest Rum distillery in Grenada and they still make Rum from sugar cane the same way they have since 1785!
5. Waterfalls - There are 18+ waterfalls in Grenada. Don’t miss these gorgeous spots & bring your suit to go for a dip! 
6. River Tubing - Head down the Balthazar River on an inter tube while you soak up the exotic island scenery! 
7. Airplanes - Check out some old abandoned airplanes at Old Pearls Airport
8. Chocolate - learn how to make Grenadian chocolate at House of Chocolate or Belmont Estate.
9. Eat Conch - You can’t visit Grenada and not try the local delicacy called “lambie” (AKA conch) 
10. Old Military Forts - For incredible views and loads of Grenadian history, walk around one of the Forts! Fort Frederick, Fort George, or Fort Matthew!

This is the season of giving. Giving doesn’t have to mean spending.  On Saturday we spent a few hours volunteering in Arlington National Cemetery with Wreaths Across America to lay Holiday Wreaths at the headstones of those who sacrificed for the greater good.

@wreathsacross mission is to Remember the fallen. Honor those who serve. And teach the next generation the value of freedom. You can join anytime by sponsoring a wreath or  volunteering with them on National Wreaths Across America Day. 

Our experience was joyous and somber. I definitely recommend volunteering at least once at a military cemetery in your area. The kids had many questions and I hope this experience helped them to build a deeper respect of their freedom & of those who defend it. 🇺🇸 

#bigbravenomad #wreathsacrossamerica #arlingtonnationalcemetery #washingtondc #seasonofgiving #arlingtonva #militaryfamily #freedomisntfree

🇺🇸 Christmas at the White House 🇺🇸 

I was having my Jackie O moment this past weekend. Baby on my hip, kids at my feet, looking out on DC from inside the White House, history all around. Now, if only Jimmy was President. 🇺🇸 

📌 Save this Post 📌 

Here are a few tips for snagging White House tickets for your next trip:
🇺🇸 You must request tour tickets from your State Congressman or Embassy. Exact info can be found on the White House website.
🇺🇸 Once you get selected, you’ll have to give a lot of personal info over for the background check
🇺🇸 We requested about 2 months early. My mom requested through Virginia and I requested through Florida. We both heard back so I canceled mine.
🇺🇸 Be flexible. You will not be able to select a specific date, so be open to touring any day you’re in DC. This gives you a greater chance of getting in. 
🇺🇸 There are many special events through the year hosted at the White House that are open to the public (with tickets) - Easter Egg Roll, Christmas Displays, Christmas, Garden Tour, etc. See if any align with your trip to Washington DC.

👉🏼 Have you ever been inside the White House?

🎆2️⃣0️⃣2️⃣3️⃣▶️4️⃣🎆

What a year, what a year!

☑️ Had a baby
☑️ Spent 87 days off the island traveling to 7 countries
☑️ Made many new friends 
☑️ Survived surgery in a foreign country, Covid, Dengue, Tonsillitis, and Pneumonia 
☑️ Read 36 books 
☑️ Achieved my biggest blogging goal of the past few years
☑️ Found the best babysitter & started focusing on me and my work
🛑 I failed at soooo many of my big goals. So many. 3 kids is a lot of kids & being present with my last infant wiped so many things off my table. I don’t feel sad about any of it. Surviving is also an accomplishment. 

I’m going to write down some goals today for this year. All small and achievable. I want this year to be my year of growth at my own pace, but not feel discouraged by lofty numbers & give up. I want my small steps to help me make bigger gains.

But at the end of 2024 I want to look back on this post and feel proud and happy of where ever I am. 

I hope each and every one of you have a great 2024!

Happy New Year! 

#yearrecap #bigbravenomad #thislittlelife #diplife #goodbye2023 #hello2024 #newyearsameme

Oh the millions of memories of our first year knowing you. 

Happy Birthday Sweet Baby

I can’t stop crying every time I try to write out how I feel. It’s been a beautifully hard and wonderful year. You were the missing piece I waited so long for. It felt like I may never get to have you, but then you showed up at just the right time. Our little Bajan baby. Our blonde haired, blue eyed Caribbean boy. We love everything about you.

Things about you today:

You’re ~21 pounds
You have 2 teeth 
You still nurse day and night 
You absolutely love your siblings
You clap, point, and sign for milk
You eat everything. You specifically love meat and savory food.
You love the water. Showers, baths, pools, ocean.
You crawl super fast and pulls up on everything, but won’t stand on your own yet.
You make the sweetest noises all day
You have a quirky little personality 
You’re obsessed with your water bottle
You say Mama, Dada, Yetta (Charletta), Cat, Hi, Uh-Oh, and random other things we catch you saying 
You smell like heaven 
You hum loudly before falling asleep

I hope I can remember all of you at this age. 

You’ve been the brightest light of our year. We love you so sweet baby Ira.

#firstbirthday #lastbaby #thirdkid #momof3 #birthdaywishes #bigbravenomad

Canyon Overlook Trail, Zion National Park

📌 Save This Reel 📌 

We did a lot of hiking in Zion (including West Rim Trail to the start of the Angel’s landing trail) and this was by far our favorite family hike. (Kids were 4 & 5)

🥾: This is a moderate 1 mile trail with limited parking at the trailhead.

🗺️ : As soon as you exit the tunnel (going away from the valley) there is a small parking lot on your right-hand side. The trail starts right across the street.

🥾: Family friendly but keep a close eye on children as there is some steep cliffs on your way up.

🧊: Use caution after rain or snow. It can be slippery in areas.

🪨 : Save a few minutes to check out the big rock alcove on the trail. We spent some time there enjoying the cool views from inside looking out. 

🚌: The shuttle does NOT stop at this trailhead
